The  Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard  and the  Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society at Harvard University   will host at least one fellow for an academic year to carry out a research project on #journalism #innovation. Candidates must propose a project relating to journalism’s digital transformation. Examples might include ideas for new revenue streams to fund journalism, the construction of new tools for reporting or research into news consumption patterns. POP QUIZ: What do you think is the best motivator for employees? a. cash b. free pizza c. praise and commendation Dan Ariely, Duke professor of psych. and behavioral economics, shared an experiment in which employees working at a semi-conductor factory were promised 1 of 3 things if they could assemble a certain number of chips per day: • A cash bonus of about $30 • A voucher for a free pizza • A complimentary text message of “Well done!” from the boss Interestingly, pizza was the top motivator on day 1—increasing productivity by 6.7 percent over the control group. This is surprising considering the cash only motivated a 4.9 percent increase...and actually resulted in a 6.5 percent drop in productivity for the week. But even more interesting was what turned out to be the biggest motivator:  The compliment. Now, if the promise of a simple text message from the boss can increase productivity, can you imagine what real, sincere, and authentic praise would do? Read more about how to make YOUR praise authentic in my book: "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence." https://amzn.to/2sxFLho #EmotionalIntelligence   #leadership   #management   #PersonalDevelopment   #BestAdvice   #BusinessIntelligence   #careers   #culture   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

BREAKING NEWS! A woman staying at the Duesseldorf University Hospital died during a ransomware attack. It could be the first death directly linked to a cyberattack on a hospital. During the attack, the hospital couldn’t accept emergency patients and the woman was sent to a healthcare facility around 20 miles away. It's going to be extremely hard to catch these bad actors. What healthcare institutions can do is to prepare for such attacks by upgrading their cybersecurity systems.  I wonder how many hospitals worldwide employ cybersecurity experts. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #cybersecurity

This excellent article by  Chip Cutter  from his interview with New York architect  Vishaan  Chakrabarti casts light on the drab uniformity of today’s modern urban landscapes.  This is of particular relevance to Asia, where I live. So much of the beauty and distinctiveness of local architectural traditions, many dating back hundreds or thousands of years, have been literally bulldozed into oblivion, replaced by Western temples of consumerism.  Like the hutongs and courtyard homes of Beijing, or the grey brick shikumen style archways and homes of Shanghai, or the red brick structures of old Taipei. These are all almost entirely gone, replaced by the dull, utilitarian and frankly downright depressing structures we find ourselves in today.

Measuring heart rate by smartwatches and fitness trackers seem to not always work on darker skin or tattoos.  I knew of this issue and similar biases in A.I., also highlighted in The Medical Futurist e-book ‘A Guide to Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare’. I’m really glad Nicole Mpofu reached out to me and raised my attention to how they’re trying to tackle this issue  Codethink . Their team is working on designing a fully open-source research device for experimenting with shining light into skin and detecting the light that reflects, gets absorbed and passes through. The kind of technology that is widely deployed for measuring heart rates. Have you heard of any similar issues and solutions? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #wearable   #health   #healthy

For so many of us, 2020 has been the year that won’t let up.😫 In these crazy times,  #uncertainty  continues to plague us in business can be crippling—or empowering—if we allow it to be. Here are some reminders to help you navigate a “what if” world: You can’t control what happens; you can only control how you respond.✅ No one asked for the year that 2020 has been and continues to be. Rather than ponder why this is happening and lament circumstances affecting your  #career , remember there is one thing you can control: your response. Be mindful of what you consume.🧠 “You are what you eat” doesn’t only pertain to food; the same can be said in terms of the information you consume and its effects on your mental and physical wellbeing. Be aware of the people and sources you allow into your orbit, limit your exposure to those that trigger you, and seek additional perspectives that provide a balance of encouragement and  #positivity . #Perspective  is everything.😄 Asking and answering “What if?” tends to bring out extreme anxiety. But remember, you always have two choices: the worst-case scenario where you’re paralyzed by fear or the best-case scenario where you allow yourself to imagine the possibilities and become empowered by the potential of good. #leadership   #awareness 
 
 
 …see more

I have found that once you can figure out distraction in one area of your life, there is a ripple effect in all areas of your life.   It took me about 5 years to write my recently-released book, Indistractable. During those five years, my life has changed tremendously.   When it comes to my work, I love to write, but I kept putting off this work that I love because I constantly got distracted.   After writing this book and learning about distraction on a deeper level, I am writing more than ever. I have also experienced improvements in my health and in my relationships with my wife and daughter. I just read an article in InsideHigherEd about the 15 new incoming students at Hampshire College. IHE referenced a Boston Globe article describing the feelings of these students and those who chose to attend elsewhere.   Because Hampshire is struggling, they limited 1st yr enrollment.  And of those accepted, only 15 students deposited.  Reflecting on small entry classes, why is  it necessarily a bad idea to be one of those students and for some, it cld be beneficial. Start w/ this: the students know the institution is struggling. They chose to go to an institution that is free spirited and now working to solve fiscal issues.   Might that be like an adventure for some? A bonding experience?  Being a part of something bigger?  Pursuing new pathway in higher ed?  Isn’t that the Hampshire way?  Anti-complacency?  Yes, it might be a costly student experiment—financially and otherwise. But, this is not pro forma college with consistency; this is like an entrepreneur’s start up.  I raise this because I’m still struggling to save a small college that wld clearly need a soft reboot. I don’t think all students wld avoid that. Some might like the effort, energy, commitment. Just saying: small entry classes aren’t all bad. These 15 students are bold and brave.  Bravo/brava. Rainbows.

Until recently, the 406 students from Pelinia, a remote village in the Drochia district of northern  #Moldova , had no  #toilets  inside their school building. Like many buildings across the country, there was no sewerage system installed, which left them having to brave all sorts of weather to simply use the bathroom. The lack of running water also meant the simple outdoor facilities were often unhygienic. In 2017, 40-year old history teacher,  ludmila turcanu  ( https://lnkd.in/dyh5brg ) herself from Pelinia and a graduate from its local school, along with four other female teachers and a student decided to change this situation. Read about their empowered, inspiring efforts to improve the health and futures of their nation's children via  UN Women . #globalhealth   #globaldevelopment   Women in Global Health   #water   #sanitation   #hygiene   #WASH   #HealthForAll   #childhealth   #education   https://lnkd.in/dWWgyvX

According to National Geographic, “Extinction rates today are hundreds—perhaps thousands—of times higher. The last mass extinction, which did in the dinosaurs some 66 million years ago, followed an asteroid impact. Today the cause of extinction seems more diffuse. It’s logging and poaching and introduced pathogens and climate change and overfishing and ocean acidification. But trace all these back and you find yourself face-to-face with the same culprit. This time around, the asteroid is us." The photograph below shows the gap between what people in each country perceive as the percentage of protected land and water v/s what happens in reality. This made me think how we can be cocoon in our perceptions. How much do you think about climate change and personal choices? (Article link in comments)

The Medical Billing Advocates of America and CoPatient, claims 75 - 80% of medical bills have some sort of error, which are usually in the care provider's favor. That's why I'm so excited about this bill to push transparency and fair healthcare costs forward. Imagine waking up one morning and you can't see - which is what happened to me when I was running daily, practicing a very healthy lifestyle. In the blink of an eye, I was faced with six digits of medical debt. It could happen to you. Chronic illness doesn't discriminate. Strokes and heart attacks can cause permanent damage and insane medical bills. We can do better than this. Good health shouldn't depend on how much money you have in your wallet. #inclusion   #healthcare   #chronicillness   #invisibledisability   #publicspeaker   #chantelshares

#Socialmedia  notifications aren’t just robbing your time and  #attention ; they’re also increasing your stress and anxiety.📲   Here’s why you should turn them off:   You’ll start your day less anxious🧘‍♀️ Instead of starting your day with a sense of dread, you’ll feel calm and peaceful, knowing that you’re not allowing external forces to dictate your mood.   It redirects your behavior to support conscious and intentional consumption🎯 When you reclaim your time as your own, you decide when you want to check and engage on social media.   You’ll have uninterrupted blocks of time to do deep work⏰ When you protect your time, you’ll find it easier to have blocks of time to immerse yourself in deep work.   You’ll be more productive and less busy✅ When you’re not scrolling through and checking notifications, you’ll have more time to do the things that matter most.   You’ll be more present for others❤️ When your notifications are off, your attention won’t be compromised, and you’ll be more present for those that matter most.   It reminds you of what’s truly urgent and important⚠️ With notifications off, you’ll realize that not everything requires an instant response, and not much is truly important and urgent.   #leadership   #career   #timemanagement   #productivity 
 
 
 …see more

Thank you,  Alan Watt , for sharing this link to a  BBC  video about  #pregnancy  and  #childbirth  experiences for black women in the  #UK .  The statistics don't lie:  just as with African American women, the  #maternalmortality  rates for black women in the UK are five times higher than for white women. This video powerfully explains the core issue: the lived experiences for these women, and how they are treated during interactions with doctors, nurses and even some  #midwives  in pregnancy and delivery settings. This is such a complicated issue, and content that helps explain the crisis is urgently needed.  #globalhealth   #maternalhealth   #reproductivehealth   #reproductivejustice

In 1980 I visited President Jimmy Carter in the White House. I was obsessed with politics. With the people who worked so hard to be “governor” or “Senator” or “president”. I think it was because I was insecure. I didn’t want to be just me. I wanted people to like me, to maybe even VOTE for me. At age 12. When my friends were starting to hold hands with girls and feel that first unusual stirrings of romance, I would go home every day and call Senators and Governors and Presidential candidates for hours. I would write letters to them, maybe 50 letters a day, and steal the stamps from my parents. . . . . #lifestyle #politics #democrate #entrepreneur #writing

Did you know that nearly 80% of what we see on social media isn't even real? #Instagram  is filled with pretend models, posing in front of cars and stacks of cash that aren't theirs. #Facebook  is filled with ads for entrepreneurs with fluffy business models that won't pan out for most. Even on  #LinkedIn  many creators / founders / owners that aren't nearly as successful as they portray - even some with a track record of fraudulent behavior! Now don't worry, nothing is wrong with your device... 😱 I'm just simply not wearing makeup... 😱 Didn't use a filter... 😱 Or any video softening tools. Because you NEED to remind yourself to be cautious of everything you consume on the internet. 👉NEVER compare. 👉Don't envy strangers. 👉Channel those emotions into fuel to propel yourself FORWARD. And ALWAYS make sure to perform a background check on potential business partners. When attempting to understand the causes of distraction, it’s incredibly easy to assign blame to technology.  A quick Google search will turn up countless headlines:  “Technology is driving us to distraction” “Smartphones make people distracted and unproductive” “Why we're living in a dark age of technological distraction” The truth is that digital distraction is a symptom, not the sickness. When we put all the blame on tech, the root causes stay hidden.  Unless we deal with the root causes of our distraction, we'll continue to find ways to distract ourselves. I've messed up. Because I haven't shown what it's really like owning a business. Here's "my" reality of being an entrepreneur. ✅ I've had two failed businesses. In 2018 my power was turned off multiple times because I wasn't making enough money. Early 2019, I slept on my office floor for 2 months while we got our company off the ground. ✅ My company has grown quickly. And it's been amazing. But 2019 was also a rough year. I skipped pay multiple times.  ✅ I had to walk miles to meetings because I totaled my car and didn't have enough money for Lyft. ✅ I rented out two of my apartment rooms at $500 a month each. It allowed me to live rent free a lot of 2018 while I focused on building my company. ✅ I've been called a 'n***er'. Laughed at during the first pitch event I ever went to. Friends turn into enemies. Fellow creators turn on me.  Don't become an entrepreneur because of what it looks like. This is the worst thing I've ever done in my life.  But it's also the most rewarding thing I have ever done. And I can't imagine doing anything else. I'm a business owner because of the freedom. Because it fuels my curiosity. Because it allows me to empower others. Share this video with someone that needs to see this! 🎥  #justQ  🖖🏾🖤  #entrepreneurship   #business

My TEDx was about standing out with a story. And there are few things that illustrate the power of story better than this.👇🏽 In the 60s a Harvard Psychologist, Robert Rosenthal, approached a school in California. Basically saying, “hey, I have this test I can give your students to help you identify which students are special.” The kids were then separated into two groups “average” and “special”. A year went by and the test was incredibly accurate. The “special” group blew the other group out of the water in everything from: test scores, curiosity, happiness, etc. Even the teachers were happier. The thing is, that test was 100% bullshit and the students were chosen at random.  So 1). A good story can help sell anything. And 2). Pay attention to the narratives that you’re telling yourself. Because stories have the power to create reality. #justQ  🖖🏽🖤  #entrepreneurship   #PublicSpeaking

Americans spend $19B a year on gym memberships. Unfortunately, 44% of people quit just six months after joining. These numbers are disheartening, but not overly surprising. Humans are hardwired to chase short-term rewards over long-term benefits. I have struggled with working out for as long as I can remember, so I know that dichotomy all too well. As an obese child, my mother dragged me to the gym to no avail. As a lazy teenager, I desperately joined the wrestling team and never won a match. As an adult, I have tried to prioritize fitness many times, but have failed at each attempt. This was until I found Fitbod, a great app that has helped me consistently go to the gym for over two years. Beautifully designed and with over 3M downloads, it is among the highest grossing and highest rated apps on the Apple App Store. Fitbod has been more than useful to me, but I was surprised to learn that my book, Hooked, was useful to their founders. Fitbod is  Allen Chen 's brainchild and he told me that he designed the initial prototype based on the four parts of the Hooked Model. He identified the internal trigger as not knowing what to do at the gym. Check out the link ⇒  http://bit.ly/2WsOuPM #Hooked   #InternalTrigger   #Indistractable   #Fitness   #Fitbod

I recommend watching this video all the way through. Google admitted to The Verge that it is disturbing, "It is designed to be." But there's something undeniably "Brave New World" about it. Leaving aside the creepiness, the premise seems to be built upon the assumption that understanding the past and present is key to predicting the future. History tells us this is at best only partially true. Even if Google one day manages to harness billions of user data points to help coerce the desired behavior from both the individual and the wider population, I suspect chaos theory will kick in at some point: you cannot predict the unpredictable. To quote Dr Ian Malcolm from Jurassic Park, "Life will find a way" #futurism #technologytrends

When it came to exposing their bad loans, Indian banks had been belly dancing but the Reserve Bank of India forced them to do a striptease. Want to read more on this? Read Tamal Bandyopadhyay's `From Lehman to Demonetization'. It describes graphically how some public-sector banks have been driving down the slow lane to death, loaded with bad assets. Many of the loans that had been restructured following the Lehman collapse continued to haunt them but they were in a denial mode till Raghuram Rajan drove the first of  its kind asset quality review, or AQR, for these banks.  The has traced the rise in the bad debts of Indian banks and tried to go to the roots—as to why assets go bad. Is it the inefficiency of the management? Is it the interference of the government? Rogue corporations? Or, is it about business cycles going bust?  To read the book, visit:  http://amzn.to/2AucbeQ 
 
 
 …see more

You’re only one decision away from a totally different life. Making a positive, life-changing decision requires three steps for success: 1. Awareness When we’re unhappy, it can often feel like there’s no way out, but you always have options. The first step in making a  #choice  is the  #awareness  that you have one. At this stage, it’s not about editing yourself on what’s possible; it’s about being mindful that change starts with you and your attitude. (Note: choosing not to make a change is also a choice; if you’re not changing it, you’re choosing it.) 2. Attention with Intention Once you’ve realized that change is an internal job, consider those things within your control and how they impact—for better or worse—what you want. Bring your  #attention  to your  #intention , and ask yourself what’s the one thing you can do right now to bring you closer to your  #goals . This need not be a grandiose, sweeping gesture; the biggest change starts with a small step in a new direction. 3. Action This last step may seem obvious, but far too often, we fail to act even when we know that making a change is in our best interest. Nothing changes if nothing changes. And action begets more action, giving us the much-needed momentum to keep going, no matter how slowly we start. #leadership   #career

Firings forced me to look at my life situation, take a bigger picture than I was taking, and figure out the new slices of life I can now taste. Being rejected is an invitation to sample more from life. And having a checklist helped me ignore all the bad chemicals that were trying to bring me down. #Madoff forced me to look at my life with a bigger lens. I started new businesses. I channeled my frustration into more networking, into ideas, into experimenting with my creativity to try new careers. I do the items on this checklist almost every day. Thank you Bernie Madoff. You did very bad things. And I met you when I was lost in my life. This is not about you. Or about me. It's what you and I did together. Here they are... 10 things you need to do if you were #fired yesterday:  http://ow.ly/YhRN30iRjU6

I am so happy to see  #SupremeCourt  Justice  #RuthBaderGinsburg  at the top of this list of The Most Influential People in Global Policy for 2019. She's the reason I can spring out of bed at 5:15 am most mornings.  She helps me realize that I don't have the luxury to give up or give in. That no matter what your age or station in life is, as a woman you have a voice, and you have the right to use it. And you MUST use it. Her example teaches me that, God willing, I'll have another 20 or 30 years left to try to make a difference, to contribute something positive to this world if I work hard to stay healthy and strong. I'll be posting about some of the other amazing women on this list over the coming weeks, because these days,  #genderequality  is MY JAM!  Thanks to @Apolitical for compiling this list, drawn from over 9,000 nominations. It recognises and celebrates the hard work being done on  #genderpolicy  by so many around the world.  #genderequity   #womenandgirls   #womensrights   #humanrights   #reproductivehealth   #reproductivejustice

I count myself fortunate to have spent time with Brooklyn-born Arnold Packer. Arnold was the Assistant Secretary for Policy, Evaluation, and Research in the U.S. Department of Labor during the Carter administration. His insights and innovative thinking around economics, employment and training policies helped many people, particularly young people to reach their full potential.  Arnold passed away aged 85 in mid-October. The last project we were working up with my colleage  Ervin Dimeny  was around verified resumes. Thanks to the  Urban Institute  report by  Robert Lerman   Daniel Kuehn  and  Pamela Loprest   - wonderful insights into the topic. Game suppliers from all over the globe have recognised the needs of players as well as the massive potential for further growth of the socially distanced form of entertainment. As a result, they have invested heavily in virtual reality and augmented reality elements, improved gameplay and cutting-edge graphics to bring the entire experience to a new level for consumers. These leaders realize that it’s not about them, and know that to  #communicate  and  #connect , they must put other people’s needs first.   Positive leaders tend to have a growth  #mindset  or one in which they believe they can—and will—improve, and see every opportunity as a chance to grow and learn. “Just checking in.” ⚠️ WARNING! ⚠️  Using “just” doesn’t make you sound less aggressive; it weakens your message, dilutes its impact, and signals that you and your request aren’t very important. Here’s how to drop it: First, become more mindful of your words🧠 Scan your  #emails , texts, and messages (and better yet, read them out loud). You might be shocked to learn how often that seemingly innocuous word pops up in  #communication .  Next, determine what you want🎯 Identify if you’re looking for a status update or trying to stay on someone’s radar—as well as the urgency— so you can craft an appropriate message. Finally, substitute new, action-oriented phrases🚀 Instead of “just checking in,” which screams “this isn’t important or timely” to your intended audience, try an equally polite but far more direct approach: “I’d love to hear how the (EVENT/PROJECT) is going/went. Could you give me a quick status update by end-of-day?” Or “Yikes! If your inbox is anything like mine, messages tend to get buried. I wanted to make sure things were still in progress. Let me know if you need any help.” By removing “just” from your  #business   #writing , you’ll add more power to your words and, more importantly, improve your chances of a speedy response. #leadership   #career   #IlluminateMe

How do you even begin to persuade someone who sees the world completely differently than you do? You must provide evidence they're likely to respect. Remember that people differ in background, upbringing, and culture; what one person finds convincing may not work for another. That’s why you must closely examine the arguments of your conversation partner. Ask yourself: •	Who influences and inspires them?  •	What research or sources do they cite?  Next, you can seek data and expert opinions from sources they are likely to heed. (Be careful not to misquote or take information out of context, which will erode your credibility.) These efforts are time-consuming and challenging. But it’s a well-spent investment, because it allows you to present evidence in a way that’s more appealing to your partner instead of wasting time on arguments they’re never likely to consider. Read more about how to achieve emotionally intelligent influence in Ch 6 of my new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho   #EmotionalIntelligence   #BestAdvice   #leadership   #empathy   #PersonalDevelopment   #management   #negotiation   #relationships   #influence   #respect   #EQ   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

3D bioprinting has recently seen some setbacks, especially due to Organovo's announcement about changing the company's course.  But this is something to provide hope again. A novel type of ink enables bioengineers to print bone-like material at room temperature with living cells. It's a big feat considering the fact that bone is a mixture of living and inorganic compounds in a highly structured mineral matrix. The team is trying to print larger samples and has begun small animal tests to see if a print can repair a large wound. In the US, the FDA has already signaled that 3D-printed bone technologies are eligible for FDA clearance. I’ve explored what 3D bioprinting can do today and what it promises for tomorrow in various parts of my e-books on The Medical Futurist. Steve Jobs is best known for conducting one of the most stunning business turnarounds in history: leading Apple from the brink of bankruptcy to become the most valuable company in the world.  But many who worked with the famous founder had a love/hate relationship with their boss. Yes, he was inspiring and innovative. But he could also be overbearing, impatient, arrogant. In fact, it was those latter traits that led to Jobs infamously leaving Apple back in 1985, as Jobs and Apple's board simply couldn't see eye to eye. In the eyes of many, Jobs was a "brilliant jerk." So why is it, you may ask, that in a world that seems to increasingly value collaboration and soft skills like emotional intelligence, do brilliant jerks continue to succeed? The answer's not as simple as you think. (Read more in today's column.) #apple   #emotionalintelligence   #SteveJobs   #management   #leadership   #brilliantjerks   #eqapplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

Have you ever wondered how generalists thrive in a specialized world? I recently had a chance to sit down with  David Epstein , author of Range, a fantastic book that covers this topic. Personally, I found the concepts of kind and wicked learning environments to be an interesting part of the book. David’s message: “In wicked learning environments, breadth is the hack.” Watch the clip below and leave us a comment about how you’ve found that having a breadth of experience or specialization has helped in your career or facilitated your learning! #Specialization   #CrossFunctionality   #Generalist   #Range   #Indistractable P.S. David’s book, Range, and my new book, Indistractable, were recently placed on the BookPal Longlist for the 2019 Outstanding Works of Literature (OWL) Award in the “Big Idea” category. The five books in each of the fifteen categories represent the top reading recommendations for individuals and teams to inspire new ideas, expand perspectives, and fall in love with reading. Congrats to all other authors and works on the Longlist! Check out the full release at the link in the comments below. 
 
 
 …see more

Dogs are people’s best friends…Especially Now.
 
 Studies show that they help us lower our blood pressure and deal with stress. But we don’t need studies to tell us what we know already! Dogs also help us get more exercise and spend more time in nature. They always love us and they are always happy to see us. In some ways, dogs show us what ‘goodness’ looks like in all of us too!
 
 Due to the ongoing pandemic, there has been an onslaught of negative news that can cause us to get mired in the spiral of depressing articles. However, it seems that a spike in dog adoptions during COVID-19 is one positive outcome that we can feel good about, as adoptions increased significantly in March and April. 
 
 So if you have a dog, or cat, or are thinking of adopting, make sure you have the  time--and love in your heart—to commit to them…Like they will commit to you.
 
 FTI Consulting’s Lindi Jarvis, CA, CFA, CPA CFF, and Vincent Flores, CFE contributed to this story.

Guido van Rossum , Creator of the Python programming language.

Do you think about what you consume? I am not talking about food. I am talking about all your intellectual and digital consumption habits…the books you read, the shows you watch, the instagram accounts you follow. Here’s why -  Your output is only ever going to be as good as your input. I am downright snobbish about how I spend my time and what I consume. I don't mindlessly scroll through social media feeds. (I don’t even have Facebook downloaded on my phone - shhh). Your mental input will determine the quality of your life. And THAT is how you stay on track with your goals, aspirations, and hopes for life. What’s something you consume daily that you could trade for a better substitute? P.S. - Pre-COVID, I loved exploring new cities after my keynote. Great way to get fresh input. This was taken in London. People write one standard pitch and send it to thousands of people because the incremental cost of each receiver is zero.  But there should be a cost, instant blocking is one option when I have time. I’ve learned a few things about  #content :   Just because you write something doesn’t make it valuable to someone else; it’s up to the reader to decide.   If you only use your content to sell, you’ll turn people off. Instead, strive to be of service.   If you go on and on, meandering your way through a very long post with little punctuation, run-on sentences, and no clear point, you’ll lose people.   If a reader takes the time to like, comment, and share your stuff, make sure to acknowledge their kindness.   And on that note, be sure to like, comment and share other people’s content that you think your network would find valuable. If it resonated with you, it probably will with others.   The best way to discover interesting and valuable content is to read — a lot.   Follow people whose writing you admire, whether in your industry or not, and seek many sources of information, even if it makes you uncomfortable. You never know what you’ll learn and from whom. Be open.   Content can inform, entertain, persuade, or inspire. Choose wisely.   Be yourself. Write the way you speak.   And be consistent — in your creation, your voice, your sharing, your engagement.   Because my biggest takeaway is this:  Content may be king, but content comes from people. And people connect with people.

"What would you tell entrepreneurs that see your success and think you are too perfect to experience challenges?"🙄 Oh jeez. I had a fantastic call with best selling author of "Why Me First" and Mindset/Performance Coach,  Kajal Khurana  from Singapore. I had to contain my laughter on-air because I've been dealing with rejection a bit more than usual. Three opportunities fell apart over the past two weeks. A rejection from a local publication for the second time. Personal health issues. And more... But at this moment when I was supposed to mentor others, I was able to recenter and digest my own advice. ⬇ Lean into the rejection and understand that there is more out there for you. Your future holds greater things and losing these opportunities makes room for even BIGGER ones! Sometimes rejection is proof that you are going OUT there and doing MORE 👉 and that's a sign of effort on its own! Be proud of how far you've come, even if it isn't where you thought you should be. Agree? 👇 #Rejection

In the formative stages of a startup, hiring the right talent is among the most important things a founder will have to do. And it’ll be worth considering tapping into the skills and expertise of senior professionals while they are at it.  I am reminded of the book ‘Outliers’ by Malcolm Gladwell where he notes that 10,000 hours is the magic number for greatness. That you need to have practiced and to have apprenticed for at least 10,000 hours before you get good at a task. In fact, senior professionals and retirees come having incubated their skills and talent for much longer than that. And, therefore, they are worth more for their experience than what their age accredits them with. Whether you engage them full-time or part-time, as a consultant or as a part of the in-house team, it’s certainly a good idea for young founders enroll the expertise of someone who’s navigated the deep waters of a formal organization and can guide them in their journey to building one. Perhaps I am so much in favor of this because I am aging myself! Nevertheless, with average lifespan expected to improve in the years to come - 120 years as per some estimates - we have to start thinking about longer-term productivity measures and workforce inclusion.

I don't know when ageist, misogynistic name bullying became a thing and acceptable, but it would be really awesome it that would stop. Someone's mother, daughter, sister, relative, friend is named Karen. Or Susan. Or Jenny. Or Sally. As someone who has personally been name bullied for years, I can tell you that it's not "cool" or "socially acceptable". It's ignorant, and hurtful. If you're using the Karen meme/reference (or Susan, or any other name), I kindly ask you to stop. If you see others doing that, please take the time to educate them that it's not OK to make people feel ashamed of their name, and kindly ask them to stop.  #kindness   #humanity   #dobetter

For a  #FlashbackFriday  during  #WorldBreastfeedingWeek2019 , I'm thinking back to the June 2018 graduation ceremony for  #midwives  at the  #EdnaAdanUniversity  in  #Hargeisa ,  #Somaliland . That's when I met some of the most enthusiastic, energetic and inspiring women I will EVER meet. Many had overcome incredible odds to have the privilege of being mentored by  Edna Adan Ismail . One of the young midwives I met, Kaltoun Yasin, sent me a  Facebook  instant message today to let me know that she is participating in  Harvard University 's  summer  #globalhealth  program, and that she led a presentation on  #maternalmortality  and  #morbidity  yesterday. Kaltoun took great pride in telling the audience that Madame Edna has surpassed her original goal of training 1,000 midwives in Somaliland, and that maternal deaths have dropped significantly since the training program began. At a time when I almost dread engaging with  #socialmedia  each day, I was so grateful that Kaltoun reached out to share her fantastic news. I'm determined to counteract the toxin and negativity in this world with good news like this just as often as I can. Midwife International   Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health #midwifery   #reproductivehealth   #reproductivejustice   #midwivessavelives   #Africa   #maternalhealth

We are in the midst of the holiday season! As we approach the new year, I want to reflect on all that has happened in the past twelve months. I had a chance to travel the world, visiting beautiful countries like The United Kingdom, Australia, Thailand, and others! I released my second book, Indistractable, to an outpouring of support from all over the world. I had the opportunity to serve and impact many people through my work, resulting in recognition as a LinkedIn Top Voice in Tech for 2019 and nominations for other accolades. Above all else, I began to take back control of my attention, my time, and my life, leading to countless memories made with my family, friends, and loved ones. Through it all, I have emerged endlessly grateful for all that I am able to do and enjoy on a daily basis. I will continue to approach my work and my relationships with the same optimism that I have in the past. 2019 has been great! I have a feeling that 2020 will be even better. To you, my digital community, I say thank you for an incredible year. Happy Holidays and Happy New Year! I’ll see you in 2020! 👋 #Indistractable   #HappyHolidays   #Gratitude   #Reflection

More  Netflix  history. Prior to 2004/2005, the grey "security screen" printed on the inside of the DVD mailer that prevented people from being able to see what movie was being sent, was a tangle of grey squiggly lines.  After chatting with our Ops team, it was revealed that it didn't need to be that, it's just what was done. So, we changed it to genres instead.   Very few, if anyone, ever took the time to look inside at it. But it was an easy, low-cost way for us to express the Netflix brand. #netflix   #brand   #branding   #dvdmailer   #securityscreen

See link to learn about course and registration. $60.  https://lnkd.in/dpyNStH .     In addition to social workers, this will be a valuable course for school psychologists, educators, HR personnel, among others. The point is that many anniversaries are coming up and the prior traditions for dealing with anniversaries have changed. How do we handle the pandemic anniversary and the anniversaries of those who passed away from COVID? How do we deal with anniversaries of traumatic events like suicides and shootings and death by overdoses?  We need to plan and reflect ahead of time so we don't end up retriggering older trauma.  Hope to see you there. The time to do the planning is now.

Our sales team called themselves "data slingers."  10 years ago I was hired by  Mark J. Feldman  to grow a data services brand in a then-emerging  #B2B   #martech  space.  There were only ~100 tools on the map as  #demandgen  teams bought our prospect lists to fuel email/call blitzes.  Some did it well, others simply spammed the living daylights out of those CSV files. Today, not much has changed, and yet, everything is different. Over a decade later, even with 10x more tools, the task of acquiring contacts still threatens to derail even the best laid plans - but this time, it's  #ABM  at risk.  Why can't teams find the right contacts for accounts? Why don't more demand gen pros think in an account-based way, like Sales? Are we ever going to shake our MQL-based ethos? Mark is now the head of revenue operations at Localytics, and I've asked him back for a reunion with me live this Friday at 1:00pm ET for a conversation about how things have changed in 10 years, and today, how to solve this new (but old) ABM data problem.  Live here on LinkedIn we'll dig into: - The messy yet critical task of choosing target accounts, and why less is more - How to find, and use, contact records appropriately  - The truth about working with data slingers like us See you there? 
 
 
 …see more

I want to be honest with you. 👇🏽 I quit my full time job when I was 22 to start my first company. I had no plan. And I guess long term that worked out for me.  But where I wish I could go back and reframe my thinking is this: I thought it was wrong to build something on the side.  I thought I would lose respect if I took a part-time job (even though I was struggling to keep the lights on). I looked down on people that didn’t jump all in. Which was SO naive of me.  I thought building a business was easy. Because the people I followed kind of made it look easy. One of the things I struggle with most as a creator & entrepreneur is showing the reality. I don’t show: ✅ The boring stuff. ✅ Us getting ripped apart by our business coach every week 😅😭. ✅ How much work actually goes into this. ✅ The many mistakes we make.  ✅ And I could go on and on. Thank you  Cory Savage  for prompting this thought. And thank you i.c stars for asking me to do the commencement speech this year.  2020 I want to spend more time talking about (and showing) the stuff that many of us tend to avoid. What do you wish you knew when you first started? #justQ  🖖🏽🖤  #business   #entrepreneurship

On Saturday, Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos posted a letter to Amazon employees on Instagram, detailing part of his company's strategy for the coming months in response to the novel coronavirus. One line that stuck out to me more than all the rest: "My own time and thinking is now wholly focused on COVID-19 and on how Amazon can best play its role." Take a moment to let that sink in: Time and again, Bezos has emphasized that Amazon's strategy is a long-term one, more concerned with continuing to evolve and diversify than with short-term goals and profit, something that investors have not always understood or appreciated.  But now, Bezos has made clear that he's entirely focused on adapting his business to a disease that no one even knew about a few months ago. So, what are the lessons for you & your business? The time for wishful thinking is over. The sooner you figure out a way to adapt to the effects of the coronavirus, the better the chance your business has to survive. (Read more in today's column.) #leadership   #management   #Amazon   #Microsoft   #coronavirus   #COVID19   #innovation   #EmotionalIntelligence #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

Years ago I was in my first role as a manager, and I experienced an exchange I’ll never forget.  I chastised a team member—we’ll call him David—for a major blunder. My point was valid, but I surely could have delivered it better. David’s response was quick and cutting:  “You know, you’re the kind of manager the rest of us hate.” Ouch. Of course, David could have been more tactful. But there was no use dwelling on that; there was value in this perspective.  So, I took a few moments to let my emotions settle, then came back to David. I asked him why he felt the way he did, and learned from his honesty. In the end, it made me a better manager—and it showed David that I wasn’t the jerk that he thought I was. That's the value of honest feedback, even if it hurts to hear: It will help you grow... If you let it. In Other News: A Win For Patients Personal Digital Charts as I call them, or soon to be known as ‘personal digital medical records’ are coming to your smart phone soon! Federal officials on Monday released groundbreaking rules that will let patients download their electronic health records and other health care data onto their smartphones. “Patients should have control of their records, period. Now that’s becoming a reality,” said Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar. “These rules are the start of a new chapter in how patients experience American health care.” Who are the winners? Patients, people and medical providers who want to understand, manage and control their medical and healthcare needs. Who are the losers? Electronic Medical/Health Record (EMR/EHR) companies who want to own your data to make even more money off your pain and suffering. Finally patients will have all the information at their fingertips  to help them make timely decisions —a good first step for all of us.

On the surface, the Cybertruck launch was a disaster. Even many Tesla fans admitted they thought the new E-Truck was ugly. And after Musk boasted that the truck's windows were practically unbreakable, Tesla lead designer Franz von Holzhausen, um...broke them.  But fast forward a bit. Within a week, Cybertruck had won over many of its fiercest detractors. Over 250,000 people were so enamored they were willing to deposit a hundred dollars to be among its first potential owners. So, how do Musk and co. do it? How do they manage to build products that customers are dying to get their hands on? Musk revealed the answer to that question in a recent interview: "A lot of times I think people try to make products that they think others would love but they don't love them themselves. If you don't love the product, you should not expect that others will." What and how you share your wisdom matters. Ask yourself if you’re committing these common  #thoughtleadership  sins: 1. You only share the wins Nothing is a bigger turnoff than someone who is continuously boasting. People respond to those who are genuine and admit when they’ve made a mistake. 2. You push your product or service Don’t make the mistake of using your platform for blatant self-promotion. Instead, provide value by serving, not selling.  3. You try to cover too much ground Stick to those few areas where you are expert. When you stay within your wheelhouse, your audience sees you as the go-to person. 4. You never get to the point Meandering signals that you’re unorganized and unsure. Keep to one brief, compelling message. 5. You share haphazardly or infrequently Regularly and consistently publish your wisdom, so your network looks forward to—and trusts—your insights and observations. 6. You post & ghost Merely posting isn’t enough; you want to start conversations and build relationships, so engage with those who engage with your posts. 7. You’re not telling a consistent career story People want to learn more about thought leaders. Create a cohesive, up-to-date and engaging presence that aligns with your content and supports your positioning. #personalbranding

See this new article on Princeton and women in leadership. I think it re-hashes what we know (mentoring matters) and misses culture change and self reflection.  My comment follows link:  https://lnkd.in/dTZf4wG I am struck by the total focus on mentoring for women; this is important to be sure and it is not new. What is striking is that there is almost no mention of institutional culture and the need to change that. How important is it to create an environment in which women can thrive as leaders. Were I to institute a look-see at Princeton, I would look at culture first -- what is it in the culture that enables men to seek and thrive in leadership posts. Hard to look inward and admit that there may be cultural biases and impacts and auras. Hard to face a male dominated past and current culture. Hard to be honest about what is inhibiting success. Mentoring matters for real. But, it is not enough. No indeed. 
 
 
 …see more

Recently, I shared a report that stated: "It takes roughly seven patients presenting after an abnormal pulse alert to establish one clinically actionable cardiovascular diagnosis." I described that you cannot expect one digital health technology to solve a medical issue in itself. And you cannot avoid using such technologies in healthcare to provide sufficient care. This is why digital health is a cultural transformation where you can't just drop a technology into the system and expect everything to get better. You need both patients and medical professionals to be on the same page, discuss the expectations and side effects and work together by using that technology. This is the topic that we address in the newest article on  The Medical Futurist .  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

Today we are publishing an interim edition of Sarah Jeong's 'The Internet of Garbage' available for free download on  theverge.com . Sarah recently left The Verge to join The New York Times and was almost immediately subjected to an astonishing vitriolic attack by right wing trolls. I found it genuinely horrifying to read the death threats (and far worse) directed at a colleague I knew to be anything but the racist she was inaccurately being portrayed as. Sarah, of course, dealt with it grace and humor telling me that at least the trolls were using a decent photo of her. The irony of course is that in her book (first published in 2015) is a seminal work outlining just how online harassment works. You should read it.  https://lnkd.in/dnbMHrq

I can’t stop thinking about the women and girls I met last week at the Fistula Hospital in Borama, #Somaliland. Their stories of pain and isolation were absolutely harrowing, but their strength and determination to survive, and someday thrive, still inspire me.  #Fistula is not just an abstract medical term. For tens of millions of women worldwide, the physical damage endured during childbirth can lead to a life sentence of suffering. The absence of a concession by Trump is but one of the difficult issues our students need to process and understand.  I just published a free download for educators on how to discuss the election in a non-partisan way. Once the concession issues are unfolded and addressed, I will add more to the list of teaching tools. I have also recognized that in a world of online learning, some of my books need to be made available as PDFs. That now includes the Tongue Twister book and the Lady Lucy Laugh Giraffe book, both of which are trauma responsive. They can be found at  https://lnkd.in/eaWQeJ6 .  In terms of resources, there is also a Trauma Toolbox How To Guide and The Feeling Alphabet Activity Set, also available at a reasonable price on my website. Finally, I am working on a Holiday Kit -- a type of trauma responsive bag that will help children and families navigate the inevitable changes of the coming holiday season (no Santa's lap; no in person caroling in close proximity.  Please access these resources.  Our children need them -- the amount of trauma is real and not declining.

Despite the upbeat news on the vaccines, I think we are struggling mightily across the nation with three key issues: (1) Pandemic fatigue including Zoom fatigue; (2) Absence of interpersonal touch and connectivity; and (3) Upcoming holidays and "tradition" changes that distance us.  In a sense, the second "surge" feels, at least to some of us, worse than the first surge; the numbers are perilously high; we have a dysfunctional transition of power (whatever your political persuasion) that is harming our nation. Some of us have become more isolated than perhaps even necessary due to fear as others flaunt mandates and best practices.   In a sense, we are unaccustomed and unprepared for what is happening in our nation.  We can rightly ask: how do we move forward with grace and wisdom and perspective?  What compensatory mechanisms can we deploy to help all those who need help? And, what about our children and their ability to navigate forward?   I have one thought: I have hope.  I still believe despite some evidence to the contrary that people are decent and caring and at the end of the day, the better side of humanity and the wiser voices will rise to the top and be seen and heard.  I still have hope.   Do you? 
 
 
 …see more

GOOD OR BAD: MONOGAMY  Having strong opinions are like a disease. You get one, then your friends get the same one (else, according to the rules of groupthink they are no longer friends) and so on.  I hate opinions. There always seems to be someone smarter than me who has the opposite opinion.  But I'm skeptical. And I like to know things. And think. And learn. And study. AND be entertained. And laugh.  I'm launching a new podcast soon with my friend and bestselling author, AJ Jacobs called "GOOD or BAD". We take topics: Dogs, Monogamy, Cars, Government, Billionaires, Tipping, Democracy, Cosmetic surgery, etc and argue:  "Is this good or bad?"  Sometimes we have a conclusion. Sometimes not.  Here is a teaser for one of the episodes: GOOD or BAD: Monogamy.  If you have suggestions for "good or bad" topics, please let me know in the comments.  Or, if you have opinions on monogamy, leave them in comments and I hope we read out some comments in the episode.  Enjoy! #podcast   #monogamy   #dating   #polyamory   #podcast   #opinions

Someone should coin "the law of 2020".  It means if you post something positive these days, people try hard to find the negative.  If you dare try and laugh, people will scald you. If you share good news, people will point to privilege or bad news to counteract it. Any wonderful data point is met with " yeah but what about XXXX"  If you point out the huge signs of progress in the world, people will point out your ignorance. It's driven by the media, and their accidental ( and unacknowledged addiction to cheap clicks, which play to misery and fears)  Its distorted our sense of the world, it's genuinely blinded the media to any positivity and algorithms neutralize the ability of good or reassuring news to spread.  It's like a giant self righteous woke festival of misery, a competition to be more anxious, more pious.  There is zero evidence life should be lived in a serious manner. We are all going to die. We can fight for change and justice and for better, and maybe without being so god dam miserable and judgmental and serious. It's not some giant competition to self flagellate with self imposed misery, unless I missed the "this is life in 2020" email.

TL;DR: Bravo, Microsoft. Well done!! Nine years ago, I remember having a conversation with a (now-departed) Microsoft executive about the future of Windows Phone. My take was that we would be better off monetizing Office for Mac and Android by making it available on the hundreds of millions of devices already being sold. I distinctly remember saying: "We already own the office productivity market for Desktop, this is the easiest way to win in Mobile - right now. We can fight the hardware battle another day." Emphatically, I was told that I was wrong, without any data to back up that assertion, other than, and I quote: "We will kill the iPhone."  Years later, $40+ billion wasted on Nokia, many lessons learned, we now have this: "But Microsoft has assured CNET that it's sticking with Android and has no plans to make a Windows-based phone. The company's Chief Product Officer Panos Panay was so emphatic about that fact, he told Wired so -- twice" What a tremendous cultural change by Microsoft. We’ve seen it coming but now it’s here: smart apps that are replacing-or displacing-the need for doctor’s visits! And there is probably more displacement than just doctor's visits—now Alexa can tell if your breathing is raspy due to a cold or pneumonia! It can tell if your child is autistic, it can be your post-hospital ‘visiting nurse,’ it can order your medicines when you are running low...it can comfort lonely seniors and let kids with cancer talk to other kids with cancer about their medical journey. Ok—it can’t do all this...yet...but very, very soon. And all these medical capabilities are accomplished via AI and machine learning systems--and whether it is to differentiate cardiac pain from indigestion these home monitoring devices are providing to be highly accurate—more than doctors would be. So, welcome your new Doctor/Nurse Alexa. Selected Excerpt: “These devices correctly identified agonal breathing in 97% of instances, while registering a false positive only 0.2% of the time...Alexa could send vitals to a doctor’s office before you head to your appointment and continue to monitor your condition after you get home.” 
 
 
 …see more

I can't tell you how proud and excited I'm now to share the newest e-book from  The Medical Futurist  with you. This time, we decided to try to tackle the beast: the issue of privacy in the digital health era. While the e-book focuses on practical recommendations and examples about YOUR privacy, it presents details on three levels: 1. Healthcare institutions holding on to your data (your medical records) 2. Medical data stored in the technologies you use (from fitness trackers to genetic tests) 3. Medical data stored where you aren’t aware of (from A.I. to the cloud) These three levels should be at the forefront of every privacy discussion going forward. They encompass the traditional, the new and the future spheres where our data is and will increasingly be stored. I truly hope you will find this e-book useful and I look forward to your feedback so we can keep on expanding it. #ebook   #privacy   #digitalhealth   #medicaldata   #healthcare   #futureofhealthcare   #healthtech   #themedicalfuturist

The new key factors candidates will look for in their next job post-corona. Pre-corona candidates decided to sign with companies based on 4 key factors: daily commute, the people, the role, and of course, money. Companies actually developed techniques and selling points in order to sell the positions based on these factors, and now we have a game-changer!  After some research on my side, I can tell that things are gonna change. Here are the new 4 key factors that will be considered in the post-corona era: **Financial stability of the company (the company fired staff during corona, or sent employees to unpaid leave) **Work-life balance (did the company take into consideration work hours for employees with kids, WFH)  **Social responsibility (companies that helped during the corona with donations, volunteering, and technology)  **A place to stay for the long term (according to salary, perks, and people). WDYT? What will be the new key-factors? (In the picture AppsFlyer Cares van came to cheer up our medical heroes). AppsFlyer  #covid19

In Case You Missed It: Life Saving Medicine Now (Sorta) Affordable Good News: Insulin is now only going to cost people in Colorado $100.00/month, regardless of what the insurance companies or pharmaceutical companies or middlemen want to charge patients.  (According to many sources, the cost of insulin has tripled in the last three years costing patients $6,000.00 per year!) Bad News: This is still really expensive for a lot of people —that’s $1,200.00 per year! Especially since over 100 million Americans have diabetes!  Good News: Even though you have to be a resident of Colorado to benefit from this cap, it’s a strong start and a model for all other states. Let’s hear it for common sense and great legislation. 
 
 
 …see more

Great to talk with Fox Business today on why companies should invest in Apprenticeship ?  I know many people reading this have already invested and they see the returns first hand every day.  Love to hear your experience.  For those considering taking on an apprentice or starting a program - here is some compelling reasons to give it a go... Firstly, an apprenticeship  program is one of the best investments a firm can make - U.S. Department of Labor statistics show that companies with apprenticeship programs earnt a return on investment of $1.46 for each dollar invested.  That is an average - in some sectors the ROI has been estimated at as much as $11 for every dollar invested !   Apprenticeship programs also provide employers with opportunities to improve workplace productivity, improve workforce diversity and build a pipeline of workers with the precise skills needed in your workplace (now and into the future). They can help shape the employee to your workplace culture and can strengthen your brand as an employer of choice; and finally boost employee retention.   #apprenticeship Watch:

Students in Darwin in Australia’s Top End will gain valuable real-world skills in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), thanks to the Pathways in Technology (P-TECH) Australia program. Exciting that Casuarina Senior College in Darwin is the first P-TECH in the Northern Territory. P-TECH is an innovative model of collaboration between education and industry and will provide an industry supported pathway for young people in the NT and build the skills they need for the jobs of the 21st century. Maritime and defence industries are growing quickly in the NT so the Australian Industry and Defence Network will be a key partner on this P-TECH. I was pleased to join the conversation at the inagural planning meeting with energized employers and educators at Casuarina Senior College last week. The first P-TECH school was established in the US by  IBM  in 2011 in collaboration with the New York City Department of Education, The City University of New York, and the New York City College of Technology. IBM is the industry partner for the Ballarat Federation College Partnership. #STEM Jade Moffat Herman   Amy-Lou Cowdroy-Ling   Janine McPhee   Nathan Ellery   Rashid Ferrod Davis   Sharna Peters   Louise Davis 
 
 
 …see more

I’m actually jealous  It doesn’t happen often, and never when talking about medicine or healthcare, but I’m jealous of those citizens who are already receiving the COVID-19 vaccination. So says the first recipient: “I can finally look forward to spending time with my family and friends in the new year after being on my own for most of the year.” That’s the feeling I want to have—joy, relief, self-respect and duty to my country.  Good behavior with mask wearing and good citizenship are normal parts of my behavior when it comes to COVID-19, and it takes effort—I’ve got my many masks on me all the time, hand sanitizer handy. I’m weighing going (and not going) to stores, movies, not hugging friend, not going into their homes and on it goes. And I’ll keep doing all of these things but it is getting harder to do—I mean who doesn’t want to have a cozy meal with friends? I trust science and medicine—over the last 150 years, modern healthcare has done more to improve our lifespan than any other factors—clean water, clean sanitation, antibiotics, vaccinations, dental health, are the cornerstone to our collective health and why we now live past the age of 50. So when my time comes to get vaccinated, I’ll put on my Sunday Best, roll-up my sleeve and proudly get injected. 
 
 
 …see more

When steam engines were invented, despite directly producing incredible amounts of rotary force, for about the first 20 years they were used primarily to pump water uphill to drive water wheels. This is the mistake made with most digital transformation. We make the least imaginative change, the fastest, least risky and easiest to get through accounting alteration,  by bolting on the new to what we have.  Next time you see a process with new technology ponder this. Are we adding new technology like oil, or rebuilding around the power of the new. It's 99% the former. This is all in my book.

As part of its strategy to adapt to post-pandemic times, Walmart is making some major changes to the way it runs its Supercenters: The company is introducing a new team-based operating model--and giving pay raises to tens of thousands of employees. The new model, which has already been tested at Sam’s Club and Walmart Neighborhood Market stores, includes the following: -Cross-training small teams of associates, who can then better support during busy shifts or support associates who take time off  -New leadership roles, both at the salaried and hourly level -A new pay structure and higher pay for team leads and about 165,000 hourly employees Of course, there’s no way to know in advance how well Walmart will execute on its new plans. But the basic blueprint sends a great message to employees, one that's founded on sound business strategy and emotional intelligence: People over tasks.  Breadth over depth.  Don’t just tell, show. (Read more in today's column.) #walmart   #emotionalintelligence   #criticalthinking   #leadership   #management   #eqapplied #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

While I write often about the limitations of artificial intelligence and what it can really offer in practice today, sometimes I come across developments in A.I. that not only blow my mind away but also depict an exciting vision of the future of healthcare. Look at this: In some cases, patients need injections with an iodine-based dye (radiocontrast) to make their organs more visible in scans. But some patients can’t take the dye. So researchers developed a GAN (generative adversarial network) that generates labeled, undyed CT images of lesions on kidneys, spleens, and livers. They added these images to real-world training data to improve performance of a segmentation model that marks lesions in diagnostic scans. As it's really hard to get enough quality medical data to train the algorithm on and labeled medical data is even harder to find, GANs are making it easier and less expensive to create large, annotated datasets for training A.I. diagnostic tools.   #artificialintelligence   #ai   #aihealthcare   #digitalhealth   #futureofhealthcare   #themedicalfuturist 
 
 
 …see more

2008 and 2018. I was 23 on the left and just starting my company, Zen Media. I’d just finished graduate school and writing my thesis on Twitter. No one believed social media would be a field. It was early (...very early) days. I could have never imagined the highs and lows which would follow. The following year, Business Week would name me to their 25 under 25 entrepreneurs list. Inc and Forbes would follow suit in the years to come...In the 10 years to follow, I’d write two best selling books. The Zen of Social Media Marketing (4th edition now) and Momentum. Zen Media would grow to be a globally known marketing firm with an enviable client list. I’d keynote at hundreds of events in front of thousands. I’d learn what it means to lead people and make a ton of mistakes in the process. I’d know great love and great loss. But, I’d find that in the depth of winter lay within me an invincible summer. And, I’d learn the most important lesson of all - be grateful for your highs and graceful in your lows. 💞 #10yearchallenge

Who is Responsible For Our Old People? While riding public transit today I ran across this elderly man who was displaying clear signs of dementia and appeared disheveled. He posed no risk to himself or others. Not sure if he was on his way to or from somewhere. Not sure if anyone wondered when he’d arrive or worried if he didn’t show up.  He seemed utterly alone, which seems painful given his senior years and confused state. Maybe we don’t (collectively) care...but somehow it struck a sad cord in my heart as I watched him point to no one and talk to no one. At one point in time, he was someone’s child and might be someone’s father. Where are people like this supposed to live? Who is supposed to help them. Where is our humanity—and even absent that—where is our infrastructure which should exist in a democratic society which holds that all people are created equal and deserves compassion? 
 
 
 …see more

Well, another quandary with respect to which I need some insight.  I just read the stories about the predator/ cult leader Larry Ray and his involvement with students at Sarah Lawrence College (including his own daughter).  It took a while but he was just arrested (later than necessary). The NYMagazine piece is chilling. My questions do not relate to the power of a cult figure on young people.  We have many examples of this... sadly. Here’s what I don’t get:  where were the Sarah Lawrence administrators and staff? Apparently, at least one knew something was “up” in a specific dorm and did not address the issues.  Perhaps a parent can spend a night or two or three in a dorm but Larry Ray’s stay appears to be much longer.  Didn’t folks notice?  Wasn’t there an RA?  I frankly am hard pressed to believe the College could claim to be so hands off or ignorant or accepting of parents living on campus. Weren’t red lights flashing? Lives and relationships were ruined.  What responsibility did/does Sarah Lawrence have and are the personnel then there  still employed?  Years in question seem to be 2010 — 2014.   There must be another piece or two of three that I am missing.  I have known some administrators there — remarkable people. Explain to me what happened please.

My belief is that  "The Healthcare Institutional Mindset"  (including hospitals, nursing facilities and delivering systems) is one which is fundamentally risk-adverse, backwards-thinking and myopic.  Within these organizations you will not find "skunk works" or "innovation labs" or "stealthy teams" working on new approaches to patient care. In healthcare we are designed (and hire) for being slow, cautious and repetitious ... even if doing the same thing over and over leads to the same mediocre and disappointing results. Again I say "Apple, come find me! I'm just up the road and am here to help improve care delivery for patients !" Selected excerpt: "The iPhone, which turned 10 this summer, already aggregates some health data in apps. But most of that is patient-generated. If the company can add information from doctors offices and clinics—test results, visit summaries, medication lists—the iPhone could become an important healthcare tool in achieving interoperability, which has for so long frustrated the industry."

I just watched The American Meme documentary on Netflix and it should be a cautionary tale for all of us who share our lives online. Before, content was the king. Now it's just pure attention.  What I learnt here is not that being an influencer with millions of followers without any "traditional" content or quality is bad. What I learnt that for all of us who discuss health, technology and science online, we need to learn how to get quality attention, not just how to provide quality content.  If you have a favorite online influencer in any topic you like to follow, please share which one and why.

Coping when you get sick or injured—it’s tough. My husband came home yesterday in a cast after tearing his Achilles’ tendon. And he was very irked and cranky.  Every day people break bones, sprain ankles, get diagnosed with pneumonia, chicken pox, get their hip replaced and many other ailments that require people “staying put” for a week or three. So what’s the best way to move past being mad or irritated or depressed during a period of injury or illness? Step one. Accept the current reality of the situation. Step two? Reframe the situation—For example if you are ‘bummed out’ you can’t play tennis for three months, think  ‘now an opportunity to read those books I’ve been wanting to read’ or to ‘learn to cook those four dishes that I’ve  just haven’t gotten around to...’ Truth is there’s lots that can be done during this ‘down time,’ so think ‘Crisis as Opportunity.’ 
 
 
 …see more

Yesterday, I gave a keynote about artificial intelligence's role in healthcare to a biopharma company. One of the best questions I received was about liability. Who is to blame if an A.I. algorithm makes a mistake? This is a recurring issue and I like to answer it with a metaphor. If a physician listens to your heart sounds with a stethoscope and there was something wrong with the device and it misled the diagnosis, who is to blame? The manufacturer of the stethoscope? Never. The physician is supposed to be using all the available technologies at their disposal and with their expertise and knowledge therefore only they can be blamed, the final decision is their responsibility.  The same applies to the use of A.I. It is a (regulated, supervised and assessed) tool in the physician's hand and thus only contributes to the decisions, not making them.  What do you think? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

How many influential business leaders have you seen nix a little bit of fun as a waste of time and energy? This article from  The New York Times  is a refreshing reminder that "guilty-pleasures" are good for you. “A guilty pleasure is something that we enjoy, but we know we’re either not supposed to like, or that liking it says something negative about us. That negative thing often ends up being an association with categories of identity we disparage and marginalize in society.  Consider what separates sports and reality TV.  The idea of someone apologizing for watching the NBA finals sounds silly, but the implied apology when someone says, “Ugh, I know ‘The Bachelor is awful but I can’t stop watching it” is normalized." The Journal of Media Psychology conducted a study proving that playing a video game or watching a movie or television can restore some psychological resources and reduce stress. 🦄✨🦄 Yesterday I indulged in lemon bars, the purchase of a jacket covered in rainbow sequins, wearing my favorite pair of unicorn slippers while watching Dynasty on Netflix.  #NoGuilt 🦄✨🦄 BONUS READ Pleasure Activism: The Politics of Feeling Good #MentalHealth   #Leadership   #Happiness   #ChantelShares

With so many out of work, I thought I'd re-share this piece I wrote on using the "laddering" technique to understand what underlying skills you actually have. Self-assessment can be hard. When we look at "what we do" we tend to get stuck in the definitions of the roles and the industry we are in. By "laddering," and getting to those underlying skills, you can start to see that many if not all are truly applicable to other jobs and even other industries. Physical retail was broken long before the pandemic accelerated its decline. So, thinking that consumers will “go back” to what used to define the physical retail experience means believing that consumers will want to do more of what many had already decided they wanted to do less of: shop in the physical store. The only thing holding many consumers back from abandoning physical retail was inertia, something that the pandemic has motivated consumers to overcome. Now that they have there’s no turning back.

Dr. Zsuzsanna Varga, a primary care physician in Budapest, put the Ask Me About Digital sticker on her door.  She told me: “a young girl came in the other day, who saw the badge earlier that week, so she was brave enough to come in and show me the pictures she took with her phone on her urticaria that only comes in the morning. The patient also told me about how she googled her symptoms but couldn’t find any reasonable explanation. She was happy about the badge because she has mixed experiences of googling and interpreting it to healthcare practitioners. I think it’s a great possibility to get closer to younger generations because she felt safe and understood, so she won’t be hesitating next time she has any problem”. It was really hard to track down the developers of Leela Chess Zero, the highest rated chess engine today, but I managed to find them in a developer forum. It was interesting to learn that the developers are not professional chess players and they don't even need to be to develop such an algorithm.  Imagine the same in medicine. Developers creating the highest rated medical algorithm without having a profound knowledge of medicine. This is the era artificial intelligence is bringing to us. Here is how they described the algorithm works: "Leela Chess uses a neural network trained without human knowledge. The training procedure uses reinforcement learning to train the next generation of the network based on games played using the previous one against itself (“self-play”) so without any external influence. The initial network is trained using random games so there is no human input in the process. The next network improvement comes from using a (small) search tree to improve the neural network’s evaluation of a position and using this outcome, together with the game result, to train the next network. Any principles used during play are discovered this way, but not in a way that can be easily extracted as such. Obviously, the rules of chess are hard-coded in the engine." 
 
 
 …see more

Here are 24 suggestions* to help you leap into a better career:   1. Let it go Let go of those people and things that support your history, not your destiny.   2. Embrace progress over perfection Reframe failure as an opportunity to learn and take action to combat your perfectionism.   3. Build in time to reflect Slow down, stop multitasking, let your mind wander, and pay attention to what bubbles up.   4. Focus on upping your “know, like, trust” factor Share your insights, listen more, and treat people with kindness and respect.   5. Just say ‘no’ Say no if it doesn’t excite you, speak to your values, further your mission in life, or help you achieve your goals.   6. Try saying ‘yes’ Say yes to new challenges and opportunities, invite collaboration, empower and affirm others, and create an environment where it’s safe to try, fail, learn and innovate.   7. Brush up on your soft skills Use soft skills to create environments that empower and ignite teams, delight customers, and fuel sustainable growth.   8. Master time-management Do, decide, delegate or delete tasks, eliminate distractions, embrace mono-tasking, work your own rhythms, and build in breaks to recharge.   *Part 1 of 3   #career   #leadership   #progress

The  FDA ’s new A.I. action plan just got published. Here are the main points: 1. Tailored Regulatory Framework My take: As the draft guidance about this with details will come out this year, I hope adaptive algorithms will be covered. 2. Good Machine Learning Practice My take: The FDA wants to harmonize such practices across a range of international organizations. I'm not sure it’s possible, since their detailed plan is still not ready. 3. Patient-Centered Approach My take: I would’ve expected the digital health arm of the FDA to appoint a patient engagement advisory board, as promoting a patient centric approach without actively involving patients sounds like a risky business. 4. Regulatory Science Methods Related to Algorithm Bias & Robustness My take: This is why we expected that the FDA would take over our open access database of A.I.-based medical devices that we published in Nature Publishing Group's npj Digital Medicine paper. However, they confirmed to me that they won’t. 5. Real-World Performance  My take: The FDA should promote the importance of prospective studies when it comes to analyzing algorithms' performance in medical tasks.

In a world where external demands and a cacophony of noise bombard us, taking the time to turn inward and think deeply may be the ultimate luxury—and the best way to figure out what’s next in your  #career .   Here’s how:   Be intentional with your time Treat reflection as essential to your  #careerdevelopment  by scheduling time to think.   Slow down & stop multitasking It’s impossible to think deeply and carefully about your future while you’re multitasking. Slow down to find clarity among your chaos.   Eliminate distractions Up your odds for reflection success by turning off notifications, silencing your phone, and closing down tabs.   Get up & out(side) Research says walks in nature enhance brain function, reduce stress, keep you energized, and improve creativity, which enables better reflection.   Allow your mind to wander During reflection, try not to limit yourself to predetermined topics, or impose any rigid standards.   Pay attention to what bubbles up Use your self-awareness to pay attention to how you’re feeling, your reactions, and any new ideas that arise during reflection.   Record & review your thoughts so you can take action Until you capture your thoughts and goals, you’ll never be able to devise a plan of action to achieve them.   #leadership

Without trust, there can be no love, no friendship, no lasting connection between people. But where there is trust, there is motivation to act.  If you trust someone is looking after your best interests, you will do almost anything that person asks of you.  So, how can you build trust? By doing the following: 1. Listen 1st. 2. Show empathy. 3. Be authentic. 4. Set the example. 5. Be helpful. 6. Disagree and commit. 7. Be humble. 8. Be transparent. 9. Commend sincerely and specifically. Of course, some of these are easier said than done. How can you build these qualities into your daily habits? And companies, how can you build this into your organizational culture? Read the answer in my new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho #EmotionalIntelligence #empathy #leadership #management  #BestAdvice #careers #BusinessIntelligence #communication #EQApplied #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

I quit corporate life 7 years ago with some cash in the bank...I thought I would travel around the world for a year or take a two year break.  Instead, I've been learning about media and dabbling in creating content. I cover the serious topic of finance but I don't take myself too seriously. I have fun making the content. (Pic is from latest shoot in Goa!) I cover my costs such that I still have the original cash in the bank as my emergency cash fund. I say I am retired. People argue with me saying I still work...that's not retirement. Ok, call it what you will. Around the same time, someone coined financially independent, retire early (FIRE). Fine by me. What do you think - what is retirement anyway?   Would you rather learn about retirement from someone who has retired (and has finance qualifications and experience) or someone who is struggling? #personalfinance
